lesson.name: Lesson 6.1 Teacher Guide: Add and Subtract Polynomials

page.title: 6.1.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
Lesson Narrative

This opening lesson introduces students to different types of polynomials. As students gain familiarity with these polynomial expressions, they will learn to recognize like terms within these expressions and combine them whenever possible. Students will also be able to perform these same operations while representing polynomials using function notation.

Learning Goals (Teacher Facing)

Students will be able to:

  • Classify different types of polynomials as well as determine their degree.
  • Fluently add and subtract polynomials by combining like terms whenever possible.
  • Use function notation to represent polynomial functions and evaluate these functions for given values.
  • Fluently add and subtract polynomial functions while checking their work.

Learning Targets (Student Facing)

  • Determine the degree of polynomials.
  • Add and subtract polynomials.
  • Evaluate a polynomial function for a given value.
  • Add and subtract polynomial functions.

Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills (TEKS)

TEKS

Explanation of Coverage

A10(A) add and subtract polynomials of degree one and degree two;

Full coverage: Lesson provides content that covers all parts of this TEKS.

Lesson Activities

Here are the instructional activities for the lesson:

  • 6.1.1: Understanding Polynomials
  • 6.1.2: Adding and Subtracting Polynomials
    • 6.1.2: Self Check
    • 6.1.2: Additional Resources
  • 6.1.3: Evaluating a Polynomial Function for a Given Value
    • 6.1.3: Self Check
    • 6.1.3: Additional Resources
  • 6.1.4: Adding and Subtracting Polynomial Functions
    • 6.1.3: Self Check
    • 6.1.3: Additional Resources
  • 6.1.5 Reviewing Polynomial Addition and Subtraction

Students will also complete a series of problems in the 6.1.6: Practice.

Required Materials

  • Paper and pencil

Required Preparation

  • None

Lesson Vocabulary

During this lesson, it is important to:

  • Familiarize students with the vocabulary words they will see throughout the lesson. Encourage students to look for these words and notice their use and meanings.
  • Encourage students to use key vocabulary words in “math talk” and their written and oral explanations.
  • Utilize a word wall. Sample cards are located here: Mathematics Vocabulary Word Wall Cards

Vocabulary words that are emphasized in this lesson:

Previous Vocabulary

New Vocabulary

  • equation
  • term
  • monomial
  • binomial
  • trinomial
  • polynomial
  • degree of a polynomial
  • polynomial function

Support for Building Character

Throughout this unit, find ways to encourage and support students to work on cultivating their judgment.

Here are some tips to try during this lesson:

  • How Did You Do?
  • Through the Eyes of a Child

You can find other tips located here in the Playbook on Judgment from Character Lab.

page.title: 6.1.1: Understanding Polynomials
page.contents:
Warm Up (10 minutes)

This warm up familiarizes students with the different types of polynomials. Students will classify polynomials by number of terms and degree of exponent. Recognizing these differences will help students as they perform operations on polynomials of different types.

Launch

Review the new vocabulary defined at the start of the activity. After all the terms have been introduced, ask students to name a new polynomial of each type.

Arrange students into groups of 2. Have them complete the first activity sorting different types of polynomials and then answer the questions.

Student Activity

A monomial is an algebraic expression with exactly one term: \(5x^2\)

A binomial is an algebraic expression with exactly two terms: \(5x^2 + 6y^3\)

A trinomial is an algebraic expression with exactly three terms: \(5x^2 + 6y^3 - 7c\)

Monomials, binomials, and trinomials are all different types of polynomials. A polynomial is a monomial or two or more monomials combined by addition or subtraction.

Working with your partner, use the following Desmos activity to sort the polynomials below. Then enter your answers below to check your understanding.

Polynomial Sort by Type

\(x^2\)

\(c + 4\)

\(mn\)

\(8d^2 + 3e - g\)

\(b - h\)

\(15\)

\(n^2 - 7f + ab\)

\(z\)

  1. Which of the polynomials are monomials?

ANSWER: \(x^2\), \(15\), \(z\), \(mn\)

  1. Which of the polynomials are binomials?

ANSWER: \(c + 4\), \(b - h\)

  1. Which of the polynomials are trinomials?

ANSWER: \(8d^2 + 3e - g\), \(n^2 - 7f + ab\)

The degree of a polynomial is the highest degree of all its terms.

Working with your partner, use the following Desmos activity to sort the same polynomials by degree. Then enter your answers below to check your understanding.

Polynomial Sort by Degree

  1. Which of the polynomials have a degree of 0?

ANSWER: \(15\)

  1. Which of the polynomials have a degree of 1?

ANSWER: \(c + 4\), \(b - h\), \(z\), \(mn\)

  1. Which of the polynomials have a degree of 2?

ANSWER: \(x^2\), \(8d^2 + 3e - g\), \(n^2 - 7f + ab\)

Activity Synthesis

Invite students to write a polynomial of their own to share with their partner. Have their partner identify which type of polynomial it is and its degree.

Explain that identifying the type of polynomial and its degree will be important for determining how to perform different operations on them.

page.title: 6.1.2: Adding and Subtracting Polynomials
page.contents:
Activity (20 minutes)

This activity provides students practice in adding and subtracting different polynomial expressions. Students will first add and subtract monomials.

Students will then move to adding and subtracting larger polynomial expressions by focusing on combining like terms within the polynomials. For an additional challenge, have students simplify the polynomial expression under the Extending Your Thinking heading.

Launch

Answer the first two questions in the activity as a class. As students analyze the terms in question 1, \(6x^4y^2\) and \(8x^4y^2\), stress that only like terms, with the same variables having the same degree, can be added and subtracted.

Allow a moment for students to think about question 2. After soliciting the class for an answer, emphasize that when like terms are added or subtracted, the variables and exponents remain the same while the coefficients are added or subtracted.

Allow students to complete the remaining questions individually.

Student Activity

Solve these two problems as a class.

  1. Do these terms have the same variables with the same exponents? Explain your answer.

    \(6x^4y^2\)         \(8x^4y^2\)

ANSWER: Yes. Both terms have the same variables raised to the same degrees: \(x\) is raised to the fourth power, and \(y\) is squared.

  1. Add the terms together: \(6x^4y^2+8x^4y^2\). What is the sum?

ANSWER: \(14x^4y^2\)

Solve the following monomial addition and subtraction problems on your own.

  1. \(12q^2+9q^2\)

ANSWER: \(21q^2\)

  1. \(-14c^3+5c^3\)

ANSWER: \(-9c^3\)

  1. \(8g^2h^2+(-6g^2h^2)\)

ANSWER: \(2g^2h^2\)

  1. \(8mn^3p-(-5mn^3p)\)

ANSWER: \(13mn^3p\)

  1. \(-16a^2+3b^2+8a^2 \)

ANSWER: \(-8a^2+3b^2\)

  1. Can the following monomials be simplified using like terms? Explain.

    \(17a^2bc^3+6a^2b^2c^3\)

ANSWER: No, the monomial terms do not contain the same variables with the same exponents. The first term has the variable \(b\) with an exponent of 1. The second term has the variable \(b\) with an exponent of 2. The monomials are not like terms.

Solve the following polynomial addition and subtraction problems on your own.

  1. \( (5k^2+7k-2)+(7k^2+9k-4)\)

ANSWER: \(12k^2+16k-6\)

  1. \((12w^2+w-11)-(5w^2+8w+6) \)

ANSWER: \(7w^2-7w-17\)

  1. \((9h^2-4h+17)+(2h^2-9) \)

ANSWER: \(11h^2-4h+8\)

  1. \((8f^2+6fv-3v^2)-(6f^2-3v^2)\)

ANSWER: \(2f^2+6fv\)

  1. \((8z^3-6zx+3x^2)+(12z^3-4zx)\)

ANSWER: \(20z^3-10zx+3x^2\)

Student-Facing Extension

Are you ready for more?

Simplify.

\((6a^3-2a^2b)-2(ab^2+3b^3)+(2a^2b+2ab^2)\)

ANSWER: \(6a^3-6b^3\)

Here is how to solve this problem:
\((6a^3-2a^2b)-2(ab^2+3b^3)+(2a^2b+2ab^2)\)

Step 1
Distribute the multiplication over addition.
\(6a^3-2a^2b-2ab^2-6b^3+2a^2b+2ab^2\)

Step 2
Use the Commutative Property to rearrange like terms together.
\(6a^3-2a^2b+2a^2b-2ab^2+2ab^2-6b^3\)

Step 3
Combine like terms.
\(6a^3-6b^3\)

Anticipated Misconceptions

Students may think that they can combine any terms that share the same variables. Emphasize that each variable in the terms must also share the same degree for the terms to be added or subtracted.

Activity Synthesis

As students add and subtract to simplify the polynomial expressions, emphasize that the degree of the term does not change. When \(5x^2\) is added to \(6x^2\), the sum still has a degree of two, \(11x^2\). The same is true for the difference between two like terms.

Invite students to share any of the problems that gave them difficulty. Work through the addition or subtraction as a class.

6.1.2: Self Check

After the activity, students will answer the following question to check their understanding of the concepts explored in the activity.

QUESTION:

Find the sum.

\((14y^2+6y-4)+(3y^2+8y+5)\)

ANSWERS

FEEDBACK

\(17y^2+14y+1\)

That’s correct! Check yourself: By combining like terms, you can add the polynomials.

\(11y^2-2y-9\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: You need to add the polynomials instead of subtracting them. The answer is \(17y^2+14y+1\). 

\(17y^2+14y-9\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Check the constants that you added. The answer is \(17y^2+14y+1\). 

\(11y^2+14y+1\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Check your addition on the terms to the second degree. The answer is \(17y^2+14y+1\). 

6.1.2: Additional Resources

The following content is available to students who would like more support based on their experience with the self check. Students will not automatically have access to this content, so you may wish to share it with those who could benefit from it. 

Adding and Subtracting Monomials

We have learned how to simplify expressions by combining like terms. Remember, like terms must have the same variables with the same exponent. Since monomials are terms, adding and subtracting monomials is the same as combining like terms. If the monomials are like terms, we just combine them by adding or subtracting the coefficients. Remember that like terms must have the same variables with the same exponents.

These terms have the same variables and the same exponents:

  • \(5m^3n^2\)          \(2m^3n^2\)

So we can add the monomials:

  • \(5m^3n^2 + 2m^3n^2 = 7m^3n^2\)

The variables and exponents of the monomials do not change when we add or subtract them.

Try It: Adding and Subtracting Monomials

Add or subtract.

  1. \( 25y^2+15y^2\)
  2. \(16pq^3-(-7pq^3)\)

Write down your answers. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

Solution

Here is how to add and subtract:

Combine like terms to simplify the expressions.

  1. \( 25y^2+15y^2=40y^2\)
  1. \(\begin{array}{rcl}16pq^3-(-7pq^3)&=&16pq^3+7pq^3\\&=&23pq^3\end{array}\)

Adding and Subtracting Polynomials

We can think of adding and subtracting polynomials as just adding and subtracting a series of monomials. Look for the like terms—those with the same variables and the same exponent. The Commutative Property allows us to rearrange the terms to put like terms together.

Let’s look at an example.

Find the sum: \((7y^2-2y+9)+(4y^2-8y-7)\).

Step 1
Identify like terms by finding those with the same variable and same exponent.
\(({\style{color:red}7}{\style{color:red}y}^{\style{color:red}2} - {\style{color:blue}2}{\style{color:blue}y} + 9) + ({\style{color:red}4}{\style{color:red}y}^{\style{color:red}2} - {\style{color:blue}8}{\style{color:blue}y} - 7)\)

Step 2
Use the Commutative Property to rearrange like terms together. Be sure to take the appropriate sign with each term \((+/-)\).
\({\style{color:red}7}{\style{color:red}y}^{\style{color:red}2} + {\style{color:red}4}{\style{color:red}y}^{\style{color:red}2} - {\style{color:blue}2}{\style{color:blue}y} - {\style{color:blue}8}{\style{color:blue}y} + 9 - 7\)

Step 3
Combine like terms.
\({\style{color:red}1}{\style{color:red}1}{\style{color:red}y}^{\style{color:red}2} - {\style{color:blue}1}{\style{color:blue}0}{\style{color:blue}y} + 2\)


Try It: Adding and Subtracting Polynomials

Find the sum and difference. If necessary, be careful with the signs as you distribute while subtracting the polynomials.

  1. \((7x^2-4x+5)+(x^2-7x+3)\)
  2. \((9w^2-7w+5)-(2w^2-4)\)

Write down your answers. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

Solution

Here is how to find the sum and difference:

  1. \((7x^2-4x+5)+(x^2-7x+3)=8x^2-11x+8\)

  2. \(\begin{array}{rcl}(9w^2-7w+5)-(2w^2-4)&=&(9w^2-7w+5)-2w^2+4\\&=&7w^2-7w+9\end{array}\)

page.title: 6.1.3: Evaluating a Polynomial Function for a Given Value
page.contents:
Activity (20 minutes)

This activity introduces students to polynomial functions. Students will learn that evaluating a polynomial function for a given value is similar to how they have evaluated other functions in previous lessons.

Launch

Allow students to work through the problems individually. Have students work on the first 3 problems and pause the class for questions before students move on to subsequent questions.

Then, arrange students in groups of 2. Provide access to calculators. Instruct one partner in each pair to write their own polynomial function. Have the other partner generate three values between –10 and 10. Partners should exchange their values and functions. Each member should evaluate the polynomial function for each of the values given. Students should compare solutions and discuss any differences.

Student Activity

Evaluate each function for \(h(-4)\), \(h(0)\), and \(h(6)\).

  1. \(h(x) = 3x^2 - 7x - 9\)

ANSWER:
\(h(-4) = 67\)
\(h(0) = -9\)
\(h(6) = 57\)

  1. \(h(x) =-4x^2 - 3x + 2\)

ANSWER:
\(h(-4) = -50\)
\(h(0) = 2\)
\(h(6) = -160\)

  1. \(h(x) = -2x^2 - 5x +15\)

ANSWER:
\(h(-4) = 3\)
\(h(0) = 15\)
\(h(6) = -87\)

Evaluate each function for \(d(-2)\), \(d(0)\), and \(d(3)\).

  1. \( d(x) = 8x^2 - 2x + 6\)

ANSWER:
\(d(-2) = 42\)
\(d(0) = 6\)
\(d(3) = 72\)

  1. \(d(x) = -5x^2 - 4x + 10\)

ANSWER:
\(d(-2) = -2\)
\(d(0) = 10\)
\(d(3) = -47\)

  1. \( d(x) = -3x^2 + 6x + 7\)

ANSWER:
\(d(-2) = -17\)
\(d(0) = 7\)
\(d(3) = -2\)

Arrange into pairs. One partner should write their own polynomial function similar to the ones in this activity. The other partner should select 3 different values between –10 and 10. Exchange your function and values with your partner. Each member should evaluate the polynomial function for the given values. When finished, compare your answers. Did you find the same solutions? Discuss any differences you found.

Activity Synthesis

Since students have worked with functions in previous lessons, much of this activity will be familiar to them. Emphasize that polynomial functions often behave in the same way as other functions students have studied. Tell students that in the next activity, we will work on adding and subtracting polynomial functions in the same way we learned to add and subtract polynomials.

6.1.3: Self Check

After the activity, students will answer the following question to check their understanding of the concepts explored in the activity.

QUESTION:

For the function \(g(x) = 5x^2 - 8x + 4\), find \(g(-3)\).

ANSWERS

FEEDBACK

\(-17\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: When you squared –3 in the first term, did you get 9? The answer is \(g(-3) = 5(-3)^2 - 8(-3) + 4 = 5(9) + 24 + 4 = 73\).

\(13\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Did you square –3 in the first term? The answer is \(g(-3) = 5(-3)^2 - 8(-3) + 4 = 5(9) + 24 + 4 = 73\).

\(25\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Did you substitute –3 into the function? The answer is \(g(-3) = 5(-3)^2 - 8(-3) + 4 = 5(9) + 24 + 4 = 73\).

\(73\)

That’s correct! Check yourself: \(g(-3) = 5(-3)^2 - 8(-3) + 4 = 5(9) + 24 + 4 = 73\).

6.1.3: Additional Resources

The following content is available to students who would like more support based on their experience with the self check. Students will not automatically have access to this content, so you may wish to share it with those who could benefit from it.

Evaluating a Polynomial Function for a Given Value

A polynomial function is a function whose range values are defined by a polynomial. For example, \(f(x) = x^2 + 5x + 6\) and \(g(x) = 3x-4\) are polynomial functions because \(x^2 + 5x + 6\) and \(3x - 4\) are polynomials.

To evaluate a polynomial function, we will substitute the given value for the variable and then simplify using the order of operations.

Let’s look at some examples.

For the function \(f(x) = 5x^2 - 8x + 4\), find:

  1. \( f(4)\)
  2. \(f(-2)\)
  3. \(f(0)\)

  1. \(f(x)=5x^2-8x+4\)

Step 1
To find \(f(4)\), substitute \({\style{color:red}4}\) for \(x\).
\(f({\style{color:red}4})=5({\style{color:red}4})^2-8({\style{color:red}4})+4\)

Step 2
Simplify the exponents.
\(f(4)=5 \cdot 16-8(4)+4\)

Step 3
Multiply.
\(f(4)=80-32+4\)

Step 4
Simplify.
\(f(4)=52\)


  1. \(f(x)=5x^2-8x+4\)

Step 1
To find \(f(-2)\), substitute \({\style{color:red}-}{\style{color:red}2}\) for \(x\).
\(f({\style{color:red}-}{\style{color:red}2})=5({\style{color:red}-}{\style{color:red}2})^2-8({\style{color:red}-}{\style{color:red}2})+4\)

Step 2
Simplify the exponents.
\(f(-2)=5 \cdot 4-8(-2)+4\)

Step 3
Multiply.
\(f(-2)=20+15+4\)

Step 4
Simplify.
\(f(-2)=40\)


  1. \(f(x)=5x^2-8x+4\)

Step 1
To find \(f(0)\), substitute \({\style{color:red}0}\) for \(x\).
\(f({\style{color:red}0})=5({\style{color:red}0})^2-8({\style{color:red}0})+4\)

Step 2
Simplify the exponents.
\(f(0)=5 \cdot 0-8(0)+4\)

Step 3
Multiply.
\(f(0)=0+0+4\)

Step 4
Simplify.
\(f(0)=4\)


Try It: Evaluating a Polynomial Function for a Given Value

For the function \(f(x) = 3x^2 + 2x - 15\), find:

  1. \( f(3)\)
  2. \(f(-5) \)
  3. \(f(0) \)

Write down your answers. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

Solution

Here is how to evaluate the polynomial function:

  1. \( f(x) = 3x^2 + 2x - 15 \)
    \(f(3) = 3(3)^2 + 2(3) - 15\)
    \(f(3) = 3(9) + 6 - 15\)
    \(f(3) = 18\)
  1. \( f(x) = 3x^2 + 2x - 15\)
    \(f(-5) = 3(-5)^2 + 2(-5) - 15\)
    \(f(-5) = 3(25) - 10 - 15\)
    \(f(-5) = 50\)
  1. \( f(x) = 3x^2 + 2x - 15\)
    \( f(0) = 3(0)^2 + 2(0) - 15\)
    \( f(0) = -15\)

page.title: 6.1.4: Adding and Subtracting Polynomial Functions
page.contents:
Activity (15 minutes)

This activity pushes students’ mastery of adding and subtracting polynomials through the introduction of operations on polynomial functions.

As students solve the exercises, monitor for those who:

  • are confused by the function notation when performing polynomial addition and subtraction skills learned in the previous activity in this lesson.
  • do not distribute the subtraction sign through the entire function when subtracting a polynomial function.

Launch

Allow students to work through the problems individually. Have students work on the first 4 problems and pause the class for questions before students move on to subsequent questions.

Student Activity

Add the polynomial functions. Evaluate the sum for each given value.

\(z(x) = 8x^2 + 4x - 6\)          \(w(x) = -5x^2 + 2x + 3\)

  1. \( (z + w)(x) = \) ___________

ANSWER: \((z + w)(x) = 3x^2 + 6x - 3\)

  1. \( (z + w)(6) = \) ___________

ANSWER: \((z + w)(6) = 141\)

  1. \((z + w)(-9) = \) ___________

ANSWER: \((z + w)(-9) = 186\)

  1. \((z + w)(0)\) = ___________

ANSWER: \((z + w)(0) = -3\)

Subtract the polynomial functions. Evaluate the sum for each given value.

\(m(x) = -6x^2 + 2x - 8\)          \(n(x) = -x^2 - 7x - 6\)

  1. \((m - n)(x) =\) ___________

ANSWER: \((m - n)(x) = -5x^2 + 9x - 2\)

  1. \((m - n)(-2) =\) ___________

ANSWER: \((m - n)(-2) = -40\)

  1. \((m - n)(0) =\) ___________

ANSWER: \((m - n)(0) = -2\)

  1. \((m - n)(4) =\) ___________

ANSWER: \((m - n)(4) = -46\)

  1. What is a good way to check that you found the correct sum or difference when adding or subtracting polynomial functions?

ANSWER: Substitute a value for \(x\) into the individual polynomial functions. Add or subtract the results. The answer should be equal to the value you find when you substitute it into the sum or difference of the polynomial functions.

Video: Combining and Evaluating Polynomial Functions

Watch the following video to learn more about how to add and subtract polynomial functions and evaluate them at a given value:



Activity Synthesis

As discussed in the final question, emphasize that for any functions \(f(x)\) and \(g(x)\), \((f - g)(x) = f(x) - g(x)\). This can be a useful tool for evaluating that your solution to \((f - g)(x)\) is correct.

Ask students to verify this by finding \(z(6) + w(6)\) using the functions in the first part of the activity. The solution should match what they found for \((z + w)(6)\) in question 2.

6.1.4: Self Check

After the activity, students will answer the following question to check their understanding of the concepts explored in the activity.

QUESTION:

For functions \(f(x)=5x^2-4x-1\) and \(g(x)=x^2+3x+8\), find:

\((f+g)(x) =\) _______

\((f+g)(5) =\) _______

ANSWERS

FEEDBACK

\((f+g)(x) = 4x^2-x+7\)

\((f+g)(5) = 102\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Check your operations when finding \((f+g)(x)\). The answer is \((f+g)(x) = 6x^2-x+7\) and \((f+g)(5) = 152\).

\((f+g)(x) = 6x^2-x+7\)

\((f+g)(5) = 152\)

That’s correct! Check yourself: \((f+g)(x) = 5x^2-4x−1 + x^2+3x+8 = 6x^2-x+7\). Substitute 5 for \(x\) to find \((f+g)(5)\). \((f+g)(5) = 6(5)^2-(5)+7 = 150-5+7 = 152\).

\((f+g)(x) = 4x^2-7x-9\)

\((f+g)(5) = 56\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Did you find \((f-g)(x)\)? You need to find \((f+g)(x)\). The answer is \((f+g)(x) = 6x^2-x+7\) and \((f+g)(5) = 152\).

\((f+g)(x) = 6x^2-x+7\)

\((f+g)(5) = 32\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Did you square 5 in the first term when finding \((f+g)(5)\)? The answer is \((f+g)(x) = 6x^2-x+7\) and \((f+g)(5) = 152\).

6.1.4: Additional Resources

The following content is available to students who would like more support based on their experience with the self check. Students will not automatically have access to this content, so you may wish to share it with those who could benefit from it.

Adding and Subtracting Polynomial Functions

Just as polynomials can be added and subtracted, polynomial functions can also be added and subtracted.


For functions \(f(x)\) and \(g(x)\),

  • \((f + g)(x) = f(x) + g(x)\)
  • \((f - g)(x) = f(x) - g(x)\)

Let’s look at some examples.

For the functions \(f(x) = 3x^2-5x+7\) and \(g(x) = x^2-4x-3\), find:

  1. \((f+g)(x)\)
  2. \( (f+g)(3) \)
  3. \( (f-g)(x) \)
  4. \( (f-g)(-2) \)
  1. \((f+g)(x)=f(x)+g(x)\)

Step 1
Substitute \(f(x)={\style{color:red}3}{\style{color:red}x}^{\style{color:red}2}{\style{color:red}-}{\style{color:red}5}{\style{color:red}x}{\style{color:red}+}{\style{color:red}7}\) and \(g(x)={\style{color:blue}x}^{\style{color:blue}2}{\style{color:blue}-}{\style{color:blue}4}{\style{color:blue}x}{\style{color:blue}-}{\style{color:blue}3}\).
\((f+g)(x)=({\style{color:red}3}{\style{color:red}x}^{\style{color:red}2}{\style{color:red}-}{\style{color:red}5}{\style{color:red}x}{\style{color:red}+}{\style{color:red}7}){\style{color:blue}(}{\style{color:blue}x}^{\style{color:blue}2}{\style{color:blue}-}{\style{color:blue}4}{\style{color:blue}x}{\style{color:blue}-}{\style{color:blue}3}{\style{color:blue})}\)

Step 2
Rewrite without the parentheses.
\((f+g)(x)+3x^2-5x+7+x^2-4x+7-3\)

Step 3
Put like terms together.
\((f+g)(x)=3x^2+x^2-5x-4x+7-3\)

Step 4
Combine like terms.
\((f+g)(x)=4x^2-9x+4\)

In part (a), we found \((f+g)(x)\), and now are asked to find \((f+g)(3)\).


  1. \((f+g)(x)=4x^2-9x+4\)

Step 1
To find \((f+g)(3)\), substitute \(x=3\).
\((f+g)(3)=4(3)^2-9 \cdot 3+4\)

Step 2
Simplify.
\((f+g)(3)=4 \cdot 9-9 \cdot 3+ 4\)
\((f+g)(3)=36-27+4\)
\((f+g)(3)=13\)

Notice that we could have found \((f+g)(3)\) by first finding the values of \(f(3)\) and \(g(3)\) separately and then adding the results.

Step 1
Find \(f (3)\).
\(f(x)=3x^2-5x+7\)
\( f({\style{color:red}3})=3({\style{color:red}3})^2-5({\style{color:red}3})+7\)
\(f(3)=19\)

Step 2
Find \(g(3)\).
\(g(x)=x^2-4x-3\)
\(g(3)=-6\)

Step 3
Find \((f+g)(3)\).
\((f+g)(x)=f(x)+g(x)\)
\((f+g)(3)=f(3)+g(3)\)

Step 4
Substitute \(f(3)={\style{color:red}1}{\style{color:red}9}\) and \(g(3)= {\style{color:blue}-}{\style{color:blue}6}\).
\((f+g)(3)=19+(-6)\)
\((f+g)(3)=13\)


  1. \((f-g)(x)=f(x)-g(x)\)

Step 1
Substitute \(f(x)={\style{color:red}3}{\style{color:red}x}^{\style{color:red}2}{\style{color:red}-}{\style{color:red}5}{\style{color:red}x}{\style{color:red}+}{\style{color:red}7}\) and \(g(x)= {\style{color:blue}x}^{\style{color:blue}2}{\style{color:blue}-}{\style{color:blue}4}{\style{color:blue}x}{\style{color:blue}-}{\style{color:blue}3}\).
\((f-g)(x)=( {\style{color:red}3}{\style{color:red}x}^{\style{color:red}2}{\style{color:red}-}{\style{color:red}5}{\style{color:red}x}{\style{color:red}+}{\style{color:red}7})-({\style{color:blue}x}^{\style{color:blue}2}{\style{color:blue}-}{\style{color:blue}4}{\style{color:blue}x}{\style{color:blue}-}{\style{color:blue}3})\)

Step 2
Rewrite without the parentheses.
\((f-g)(x)=3x^2-5x+7-x^2-4x-3\)

Step 3
Put like terms together.
\((f-g)(x)=3x^2-x^2-5x+4x+7+3\)

Step 4
Combine like terms.
\((f-g)(x)=2x^2-x+10\)


  1. \((f-g)(x)=2x^2-x+10\)

Step 1
To find \((f-g)(-2)\), substitute \(x={\style{color:red}-}{\style{color:red}2}\).
\((f-g)( {\style{color:red}-}{\style{color:red}2})=2({\style{color:red}-}{\style{color:red}2})^2-({\style{color:red}-}{\style{color:red}2})+10\)

Step 2
Simplify.
\((f-g)(-2)=2 \cdot 5-(-2)+10\)
\((f-g)(-2)=20\)


Try It: Adding and Subtracting Polynomial Functions

For functions \(f(x)=2x^2-4x+3\) and \(g(x)=x^2-2x-6\), find:

  1. \((f+g)(x)\)
  2. \((f+g)(3)\)
  3. \((f-g)(x)\)
  4. \((f-g)(-2)\)

Write down your answers. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

Solution

Here is how to add and subtract the polynomial functions:

  1. \(\begin{array}{rcl}(f+g)(x)&=&(2x^2-4x+3)+(x^2-2x-6)\\&=&2x^2-4x+3+x^2-2x-6\\&=&3x^2-6x-3\end{array}\)

  2. \(\begin{array}{rcl}(f+g)(3)&=&3(3)^2-6(3)-3\\&=&3(3)^2-6(3)-3\\&=&3(9)-18-3\\&=&6\end{array}\)

  3. \(\begin{array}{rcl}(f-g)(x)&=&(2x^2-4x+3)-(x^2-2x-6)\\&=&2x^2-4x+3-x^2+2x+6\\&=&x^2-2x+9\;\end{array}\)

  4. \(\begin{array}{rcl}(f-g)(-2)&=&(-2)^2-2(-2)+9\;\\&=&(4)+4+9\;\\&=&17\;\end{array}\)

page.title: 6.1.5: Reviewing Polynomial Addition and Subtraction
page.contents:
Cool Down (5 minutes)

Student Activity

Draw a tic-tac-toe board on an extra sheet of paper. Use the polynomial functions shown here for the activity.

\(f(x) = 8x^2-6x-2\)
\(h(x) = 6x^2-4x-1\)

For each polynomial problem below, place an \(X\) on your tic-tac-toe board corresponding to the location of its matching solution.

\(16x^2-9x^2 =\) ________
\((9x^2-5x-3)+(2x^2+8x-3) =\) ________
\(f(5) - h(-2) =\) ________
\((7x^2-3x+7)-(3x^2+6x-4) =\) ________
\(f(4) =\) ________

For each polynomial problem below, place an \(O\) on your tic-tac-toe board corresponding to the location of its matching solution.

\(11x^3+12x^3 =\) ________
\(f(x) - h(x) =\) ________
\(f(x) + h(x) =\) ________
\(h(-3) =\) ________

Did the \(Xs\) or \(Os\) win the tic-tac-toe game?

ANSWER: The \(Xs\) won the game.

Xs:

\(16x^2-9x^2 = 7x^2\)
\((9x^2-5x-3)+(2x^2+8x-3) = 11x^2+3x-6\)
\(f(5) - h(-2) = 137\)
\(f(4) = 102\)
\((7x^2-3x+7)-(3x^2+6x-4) = 4x^2-9x+11\)

Os:

\(11x^3+12x^3 = 23x^3\)
\(f(x) - h(x) = 2x^2-2x-1\)
\(f(x) + h(x) = 14x^2-10x-3\)
\(h(-3) = 65\)

page.title: 6.1.7: Lesson Synthesis
page.contents:
To help students’ understanding of key points from the lesson, discuss questions such as:

  • “What is the difference between monomials, binomials, and trinomials?” (Monomials have a single term, binomials have two terms, and trinomials have three terms.)
  • “How do you determine the degree of a polynomial?” (The degree of a polynomial is the highest degree of all its terms.)
  • “How do you add or subtract polynomials?” (Polynomials are added or subtracted by combining like terms.)
  • “How do you evaluate a polynomial function for a given value?” (Substitute the given value into the function for the variable and simplify.)
  • “How do you check a sum or difference when adding or subtracting polynomial functions?” (Substitute a value for \(x\) into the individual polynomial functions. Add or subtract the results. The answer should be equal to the value you find when you substitute it into the sum or difference of the polynomial functions.)
